channel.title: Java
channel.description:
So I've had Head First Java for a few months now and have learned what I can from this book. Since I haven't had much time to really work with it [sat/act] now I can, but I've gotten to the point where this book is pretty much done.
Any recommendations? I need it[can be more than one] to be less than $100 and I can't have eBooks.
I'd really like this to be a sort of book where it isn't just copy the code, find whats wrong with it then compile and flip the page. I want something that I can get into, without it being complete waste of my time.

The Java Tutorial: A Short Course on the Basics, 4th Edition

Sharon Biocca Zakhour, Scott Hommel, Jacob Royal

A hands-on guide to the Java programming language, The Java™ Tutorial, Fourth Edition is perfect for any developer looking for a proven path to proficiency with Java SE. This popular tutorial "from th ...

4.4 out of 5 stars, ISBN: 978-0321334206, Addison-Wesley Professional, October 9, 2006

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @cows_be_sacred cows_be_sacred
item.description:
@cows_be_sacred wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:11, topic:340935”]I’d recommend ignoring people who flat-off say “don’t buy a book” if you’re a book learner.

I don’t really have any Java book recommendations, except Thinking in Java if you can stand its dry tone. I’m sure someone else does, or search for “java book” on stackoverflow.com.

There’s also a sticky at the top of this forum with a list of books in it.[/quote]
Already considered many of those and they weren’t anything special.
I’m thinking of effective java, but not yet sure.

Read full topic

There’s also a sticky at the top of this forum with a list of books in it.

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:4, topic:340935”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=437329.msg3213689#msg3213689 date=1274507328]
Java for Dummies
[/quote]
god fucking no.

Java for dummies is one of the worst java books ever. Infact the whole * for dummies series is undeniably shit.[/quote]

[quote=“abraham2119, post:7, topic:340935”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=437329.msg3213689#msg3213689 date=1274507328]
Java for Dummies
[/quote]no wonder you lack the skills necessary to properly write code[/quote]
No offense, but if you didn’t didn’t notice I was kidding that’s rather sad. It was a pun based on the OP.

Read full topic

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

abraham2119:

by the way, i would also recommend reading the vm spec as soon as possible to understand the internals of how the language works, this is actually very useful

Agreed, but I wouldn’t say it’s particularly important until he has an actual need to write things like high performance code or runescape hacks.

Read full topic

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:2, topic:340935”]Java for Dummies[/quote]no wonder you lack the skills necessary to properly write code

[quote=“BAsh, post:3, topic:340935”]don’t bother buying a book. there are plenty of online resources available. you should be compiling as you go anyway. since you’ve finished a book it might be time to work up to an IDE (eclipse = win). but make sure you get generics down pat.[/quote]eclipse +1

on topic, just use sun’s tutorials regarding these things, they are mostly basic but provide a concise idea on how to use a certain api. the most obscure tutorial on sun’s site in my opinion was the regex api though, seeing as they don’t explain many vital concepts such as lookahead/lookbehind, etc

by the way, i would also recommend reading the vm spec as soon as possible to understand the internals of how the language works, this is actually very useful

Read full topic

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Davidi2:

Java for Dummies

Will you hold your tongue until you’re more qualified to actually make recommendations? Thank you.

Do yourself a favour and just work through Sun’s tutorials. By the time you finish you will have worked with strings/stringbuilders, generics, sockets, etc. Once you’ve got a firm grasp on the syntax, maybe look into getting your hands on a copy of Josh Bloch’s “Effective Java”.
I think it’s still in 2nd edition; it basically covers many good programming practices and points out many pitfalls that you should avoid.

Read full topic

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[quote=“cows_be_sacred, post:1, topic:340935”]So I’ve had Head First Java for a few months now and have learned what I can from this book.
Since I haven’t had much time to really work with it [sat/act] now I can, but I’ve gotten to the point
where this book is pretty much done.

Any recommendations?
I need it[can be more than one] to be less than $100 and
I can’t have eBooks.

I’d really like this to be a sort of book where it isn’t just copy the code, find whats wrong with it then compile and flip the page. I want something that I can get into, without it being complete waste of my time.[/quote]

  1. Google ‘Java tutorials’
  2. Advance from private servers
  3. You are officially not a moparscaper

Read full topic

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

Davidi2:

Java for Dummies

god fucking no.

Java for dummies is one of the worst java books ever. Infact the whole * for dummies series is undeniably shit.

BAsh:

don’t bother buying a book. there are plenty of online resources available. you should be compiling as you go anyway. since you’ve finished a book it might be time to work up to an IDE (eclipse = win). but make sure you get generics down pat.

also this

Read full topic
